content.question: The figure above represents three identical lightbulbs and a 100 <math alttext="volt" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> power source, connected at the dots to six wires with the same nonzero resistance. A student measures the potential difference across each bulb, getting 68.1 <math alttext="volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for bulb <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></math>, 49.8 <math alttext="volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for bulb <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></math>, and 41.5 <math alttext="volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for bulb <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></math>. What potential difference should the student expect to measure between points <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></math> and <math alttext="T" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></math> ?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
